name: 1586_C. Omkar and Determination
description:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. Call a cell in this grid exitable if, starting at that cell, you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells. This includes the cell itself, so all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX

output:
YES

prompt:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. A cell is exitable if you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells starting at that cell; this includes the cell itself, so all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX
repair_prompt:
The problem statement looms below, filling you with determination.

Consider a grid in which some cells are empty and some cells are filled. A cell is exitable if you can exit the grid by moving up and left through only empty cells starting at that cell; this includes the cell itself, so all filled in cells are not exitable. Note that you can exit the grid from any leftmost empty cell (cell in the first column) by going left, and from any topmost empty cell (cell in the first row) by going up.

Let's call a grid determinable if, given only which cells are exitable, we can exactly determine which cells are filled in and which aren't.

You are given a grid a of dimensions n × m , i. e. a grid with n rows and m columns. You need to answer q queries (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). Each query gives two integers x_1, x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m) and asks whether the subgrid of a consisting of the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def preprocess_grid(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> List[bool]:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the determinability of each column pair.

    Args:
        grid: A list of strings representing the grid.
        n: Number of rows in the grid.
        m: Number of columns in the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of booleans where each index i represents whether the column pair (i, i+1) is determinable.
    """
    determinable = [True] * (m - 1)
    
    for col in range(m - 1):
        for row in range(n):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row][col + 1] == 'X':
                determinable[col] = False
                break
    
    return determinable

def is_determinable(preprocessed: List[bool], x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Check if the path between two columns is determinable.

    Args:
        preprocessed: A list of booleans indicating determinability of column pairs.
        x1: Starting column index.
        x2: Ending column index.

    Returns:
        'YES' if the path is determinable, 'NO' otherwise.
    """
    for col in range(x1 - 1, x2 - 1):
        if not preprocessed[col]:
            return 'NO'
    return 'YES'

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Preprocess the grid
    preprocessed = preprocess_grid(grid, n, m)

    # Output interface
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_determinable(preprocessed, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

import numpy as np
from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each query subgrid is exitable based on preprocessed grid data.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each represented as a tuple of coordinates.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each query, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine exitability of each cell
    exitability = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)

    # Example criteria for exitability: a cell is exitable if it contains 'E'
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'E':
                exitability[i][j] = True

    results = []
    for query in queries:
        x, y = query
        if exitability[x][y]:
            results.append('YES')
        else:
            results.append('NO')

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Call the function and get results
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if a subgrid is determinable based on transitions between filled and empty cells.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each a tuple of two integers representing column indices.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of "Yes" or "No" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine transitions
    transitions = [False] * (m - 1)
    
    # Analyze transitions between filled and empty cells
    for row in range(n):
        for col in range(m - 1):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row][col + 1] == '.':
                transitions[col] = True

    # Precompute determinability for each column pair
    determinable = [False] * m
    for col in range(1, m):
        determinable[col] = determinable[col - 1] or transitions[col - 1]

    # Answer each query in constant time
    results = []
    for left, right in queries:
        if determinable[right - 1] == determinable[left - 1]:
            results.append("Yes")
        else:
            results.append("No")
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Output interface
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_subgrid_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each subgrid defined by the queries is determinable.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each a tuple (x, y).

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of "YES" or "NO" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine exitability
    # Create a list to store the exitability status of each column
    exitable = [True] * m

    # Determine which columns are blocked
    for col in range(m):
        for row in range(1, n):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row - 1][col] == 'X':
                exitable[col] = False
                break

    # Process each query
    results = []
    for x, y in queries:
        # Check if the subgrid from (1, 1) to (x, y) is determinable
        if all(exitable[col] for col in range(y)):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Output interface
    results = is_subgrid_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if subgrids are determinable based on the grid configuration.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each a tuple (l, r) representing
                                         the subgrid from column l to column r.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of "YES" or "NO" for each query indicating if the subgrid is determinable.
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to find non-determinable columns
    non_determinable = [False] * (m - 1)
    
    for col in range(m - 1):
        for row in range(1, n):
            if grid[row][col] == 'X' and grid[row - 1][col + 1] == '.':
                non_determinable[col] = True
                break

    # Precompute prefix sums for non-determinable columns
    prefix_non_determinable = [0] * m
    for col in range(1, m):
        prefix_non_determinable[col] = prefix_non_determinable[col - 1] + (1 if non_determinable[col - 1] else 0)

    # Evaluate each query using preprocessed data
    results = []
    for l, r in queries:
        # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index
        l -= 1
        r -= 1
        if prefix_non_determinable[r] - prefix_non_determinable[l] > 0:
            results.append("NO")
        else:
            results.append("YES")
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Output interface
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

import numpy as np

def preprocess_grid(grid: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid (np.ndarray): The input grid represented as a numpy array.

    Returns:
        np.ndarray: A grid where each cell contains information about its exitability.
    """
    n, m = grid.shape
    exitability_grid = np.zeros((n, m), dtype=bool)

    # Implement the actual logic for exitability
    # Assuming 'E' marks an exitable cell and cells can exit if they can reach an 'E' cell
    for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i, j] == 'E':
                exitability_grid[i, j] = True
            elif i < n - 1 and exitability_grid[i + 1, j]:
                exitability_grid[i, j] = True
            elif j > 0 and exitability_grid[i, j - 1]:
                exitability_grid[i, j] = True
            elif j < m - 1 and exitability_grid[i, j + 1]:
                exitability_grid[i, j] = True

    return exitability_grid

def is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid: np.ndarray, x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Determine if the subgrid is determinable based on exitability information.

    Args:
        exitability_grid (np.ndarray): The preprocessed grid with exitability information.
        x1 (int): The starting row index of the subgrid.
        x2 (int): The ending row index of the subgrid.

    Returns:
        str: 'YES' if the subgrid is determinable, 'NO' otherwise.
    """
    # Implement the actual logic for determinability
    # A subgrid is determinable if there is at least one exitable cell in each row of the subgrid
    for i in range(x1, x2 + 1):
        if not np.any(exitability_grid[i, :]):
            return 'NO'
    return 'YES'

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = np.array([list(input().strip()) for _ in range(n)])
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    exitability_grid = preprocess_grid(grid)
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(exitability_grid, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def is_determinable(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each query subgrid is determinable based on the exitability of its cells.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.
        queries (List[Tuple[int, int]]): List of queries, each a tuple representing a cell (row, column).

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each query, "YES" if the subgrid is determinable, otherwise "NO".
    """
    # Preprocess the grid to determine exitability
    exitability = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
    
    # Fill the exitability grid
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'E':  # Assuming 'E' marks an exitable cell
                exitability[i][j] = True
            elif i > 0 and exitability[i-1][j]:
                exitability[i][j] = True
            elif j > 0 and exitability[i][j-1]:
                exitability[i][j] = True

    # Process each query
    results = []
    for x, y in queries:
        if exitability[x-1][y-1]:  # Adjusting for 0-based index
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]
    
    results = is_determinable(n, m, grid, queries)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def preprocess_grid(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> List[List[int]]:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        grid: A list of strings representing the grid.
        n: Number of rows in the grid.
        m: Number of columns in the grid.

    Returns:
        A 2D list of integers representing the exitability status of each cell.
    """
    # Initialize a 2D list to store exitability status
    exitability = [[0] * m for _ in range(n)]
    
    # Example preprocessing logic: Mark cells as exitable if they are 'E'
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'E':
                exitability[i][j] = 1
    
    # Return the preprocessed exitability data
    return exitability

def is_determinable(preprocessed_data: List[List[int]], queries: List[Tuple[int, int]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the subgrid defined by each query is exitable.

    Args:
        preprocessed_data: A 2D list of integers representing the exitability status of each cell.
        queries: A list of tuples, each containing the coordinates of a query.

    Returns:
        A list of strings, each being 'YES' or 'NO' based on the exitability of the subgrid.
    """
    results = []
    
    for query in queries:
        x, y = query
        # Example logic: Check if the queried cell is exitable
        if preprocessed_data[x][y] == 1:
            results.append('YES')
        else:
            results.append('NO')
    
    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]
    
    # Preprocess the grid
    preprocessed_data = preprocess_grid(grid, n, m)
    
    # Get results for each query
    results = is_determinable(preprocessed_data, queries)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def preprocess_grid(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[List[bool]]:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine the exitability of each cell.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[List[bool]]: A 2D list indicating the exitability of each cell.
    """
    # Initialize a 2D list to store exitability status
    exitable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

    # Example logic to determine exitability (this needs to be defined based on problem specifics)
    # For demonstration, let's assume a cell is exitable if it contains 'E'
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'E':
                exitable[i][j] = True

    return exitable

def is_subgrid_determinable(preprocessed_grid: List[List[bool]], x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Determine if the subgrid is uniquely determinable by its exitability pattern.

    Args:
        preprocessed_grid (List[List[bool]]): The preprocessed grid with exitability information.
        x1 (int): The starting row index of the subgrid.
        x2 (int): The ending row index of the subgrid.

    Returns:
        str: 'YES' if the subgrid is determinable, 'NO' otherwise.
    """
    # Example logic to determine if a subgrid is determinable
    # For demonstration, let's assume a subgrid is determinable if all its cells are exitable
    for i in range(x1, x2 + 1):
        if not all(preprocessed_grid[i]):
            return 'NO'
    return 'YES'

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Preprocess the grid
    preprocessed_grid = preprocess_grid(n, m, grid)

    # Handle each query
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_subgrid_determinable(preprocessed_grid, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def preprocess_grid(grid: List[str], n: int, m: int) -> List[bool]:
    """Preprocess the grid to determine determinability of column pairs.

    Args:
        grid: A list of strings representing the grid.
        n: Number of rows in the grid.
        m: Number of columns in the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of booleans indicating determinability of each column pair.
    """
    # Initialize a list to store determinability of column pairs
    determinable = [True] * (m - 1)

    # Iterate over each row to check transitions between columns
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m - 1):
            # If there is a transition from filled to empty or vice versa
            if grid[i][j] == 'X' and grid[i][j + 1] == '.':
                determinable[j] = False
            elif grid[i][j] == '.' and grid[i][j + 1] == 'X':
                determinable[j] = False

    return determinable

def is_determinable(preprocessed_data: List[bool], x1: int, x2: int) -> str:
    """Determine if the subgrid between columns x1 and x2 is determinable.

    Args:
        preprocessed_data: A list of booleans from preprocess_grid.
        x1: Starting column index (1-based).
        x2: Ending column index (1-based).

    Returns:
        'YES' if the subgrid is determinable, 'NO' otherwise.
    """
    # Convert 1-based index to 0-based index
    x1 -= 1
    x2 -= 1

    # Check determinability between the columns
    for j in range(x1, x2):
        if not preprocessed_data[j]:
            return 'NO'
    return 'YES'

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    # Input interface
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    q = int(input())
    queries = [tuple(map(int, input().split())) for _ in range(q)]

    # Preprocess the grid
    preprocessed_data = preprocess_grid(grid, n, m)

    # Output interface
    for x1, x2 in queries:
        result = is_determinable(preprocessed_data, x1, x2)
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

We will use a preprocessing step to determine the exitability of each cell in the grid. This will allow us to efficiently answer each query about the determinability of subgrids. The key observation is that a subgrid is not determinable if there exists a column where a filled cell is directly above an empty cell, as this configuration can lead to multiple valid exitability configurations. We will use a list to track such columns and preprocess the grid to quickly answer the queries.

The requirements focus on determining the determinability of subgrids based on exitability. The challenge lies in efficiently processing large grids and handling numerous queries while ensuring accurate results. The solution must optimize for both time and space complexity.

- Ensure accurate determinability results
- Optimize memory usage for handling large datasets
- Provide detailed documentation for system usage

We will use a preprocessing step to determine the determinability of each column pair in the grid. By analyzing the grid's structure, we can identify transitions between filled and empty cells that affect exitability. We will use a prefix sum-like approach to efficiently answer each query in constant time after preprocessing. This approach ensures that we handle large grids and numerous queries efficiently.
examples:
Input

The first line contains two integers n, m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6, nm ≤ 10^6) — the dimensions of the grid a.

n lines follow. The y-th line contains m characters, the x-th of which is 'X' if the cell on the intersection of the the y-th row and x-th column is filled and "." if it is empty.

The next line contains a single integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of queries.

q lines follow. Each line contains two integers x_1 and x_2 (1 ≤ x_1 ≤ x_2 ≤ m), representing a query asking whether the subgrid of a containing the columns x_1, x_1 + 1, …, x_2 - 1, x_2 is determinable.

Output

For each query, output one line containing "YES" if the subgrid specified by the query is determinable and "NO" otherwise. The output is case insensitive (so "yEs" and "No" will also be accepted).

Example

Input


4 5
..XXX
...X.
...X.
...X.
5
1 3
3 3
4 5
5 5
1 5


Output


YES
YES
NO
YES
NO

Note

For each query of the example, the corresponding subgrid is displayed twice below: first in its input format, then with each cell marked as "E" if it is exitable and "N" otherwise.

For the first query: 
    
    
      
    ..X EEN  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    ... EEE  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the second query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    

Note that you can exit the grid by going left from any leftmost cell (or up from any topmost cell); you do not need to reach the top left corner cell to exit the grid.
    
    
      
      
    

For the third query: 
    
    
      
    XX NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    X. NN  
    

This subgrid cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable, because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    XX  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fourth query: 
    
    
      
    X N  
    . E  
    . E  
    . E  
    
    
    
      
      
    

For the fifth query: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX EENNN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    ...X. EEENN  
    

This query is simply the entire grid. It cannot be determined only from whether each cell is exitable because the below grid produces the above "exitability grid" as well: 
    
    
      
    ..XXX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX  
    ...XX
